DOC.HEAD: Saga of Waste Train Finally Nearing Conclusion
DOC.TEXT: There's finally light at the end of the tunnel for a train full of sewage that was rejected from two states. The 61 carloads are to be unloaded at the sewage plant where they originated, but the latest problem is cold _ it's slow work unloading frozen sludge. Rejected from dumps in Louisiana and Mississippi, the train and its 5,000 tons of waste has come home, to be returned to the Back River Waste Treatment Plant, where the ordeal began nearly three months ago. The odors that offended noses down South are now just an unpleasant memory, as workers use jackhammers and special front-end loaders to break up the frozen cargo to meet a state-imposed deadline of Dec. 31 for disposal of the sludge. George G. Balog, director of the city's Public Works Department, said Thursday that the sludge would be stored temporarily in the Back River ``winter storage lagoon,'' then disinfected and partially retreated for combining with the plant's normal output of waste.
